If you haven't seen this video, "Time" you'll probably enjoy it very much. It's based on the evolution of Toronto streets and buildings:
https://youtu.be/dUo6ZbtDZFo
But shouldn't her performance in Grey's be sufficient for the viewer to understand her character? Are we expected to watch another television show to get what's going on with her storyline?
In my mind TM plays Sarah. I'm not sure what actors play the other characters ;)

The character of CJ has a very good arc: from Press Secretary to Chief of Staff. She also carried a few episodes on her own (The Long Goodbye and Access). Not saying she should be that highly ranked but I think her importance to the story across the 7 seasons needs to be considered.
Overall I agree with others who've already posted. The list is rather odd and many characters are ranked either way too high to way too low.
Edit: spelling and grammar.

Likely none of the actors who played her relatives before were available. So they wrote this storyline about her family not being supportive and used her recovering addict issue as an excuse/reason. A bit of a stretch as far as I'm concerned but whatever (note I stopped watching Private Practice before her character appeared so I know less of her backstory).

Power was out in the Front/Parliament/Queen's Quay/York St. area from approximately 5:00 pm to 5:00 am on May 25/26. Was mentioned by Toronto Hydro via Twitter but apparently wasn't on the hydro outage map.

WRITING.TITLE: A Definitive Ranking of Every Character on The West Wing, 2014 - saw this, searched and it doesn't appear to have been posted before, so here goes!

WRITING.TEXT: Same for me. Windows open all winter. Still 28C.

Pretty much my scenario. I don't understand why the same steps that are required to turn on the air conditioning in the spring are not required in the fall with the heat. Always some guy has to come, examine it, flip some switch, some part is busted, takes weeks for it to be delivered then some time in June the air conditioning is on. Funny in the fall the heat's just on one day.
I was told by maintenance in my building not to install a window air conditioner because I would be liable if it fell out of the window and hit someone or caused any damage.

I don't think the people who post here are exactly a representative sample of all the people currently living in homes, whether that be apartments or condos who cannot control when the air conditioning is turned on. I live in one of those buildings and have been suffering with 30 degrees C for the past week or so.
I think it's time for the city to re-consider the dates for when the heat should be on. A quick examination of the temperature rates for the past couple of years probably indicates May has been a lot warmer than previously. Maybe this will pass or maybe it's permanent. I don't know how many years of data we need before we change the date. But it should at least be considered.

There is a decent story to "Grown up Movie Star". It was shot on the East coast of Canada and the cultural traditions and way of life are a prominent aspect of the film. Some elements are predictable and the story is good but breaks down a bit. However TMs performance is stellar.
Dumb bastard??

The first thing I noticed her in was, "Being Erica". I did see "Ginger Snaps 2" but I didn't know who she was at the time. I've also seen her in "Grown Up Movie Star" and "Picture Day". Both very good.
I also saw her in an episode of the television series, "Cracked":
http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2433316/?ref_=ttep_ep6

WRITING.TEXT: This reminds me of how fun (and funny) the show was. The dialogue, the scenario and the actions taken we're all lighthearted but the situation was very real and serious. Not sure when and where all that went but the show isn't like that anymore. I miss that about Grey's.
How much do documentaries pay?
I hate to break it to you (and I guess you're parents never told you about this kind of thing) it's pretty likely the goldfish died and was replaced. Probably more than once.
Cosima has a back up. Remember what Alison said: "Shes a scientist and a lesbian. Shes not going to let it slide".
They both have their bangs cut too short.

Rumour has it they filmed two endings. One where Arizona visits Callie and they have a conversation inside her house. And the other on the doorstep, which is the one we saw. Sara's contract negotiations went to the last minute and failed so they used the second scene. Ellen P. was quoted as saying a scene had been deleted in post. It's assumed she's referring to the one inside the house.
There was another scene where Mrs. Bartlet mentions having babysat Amy when she was a kid. At the time I thought it was a bit much. How many connections do the characters need?

Phenomenal!
It was fascinating to see an image you're familiar with, watch it morph through its various phases that you don't immediately recognize then all of a sudden it takes shape and you know exactly what building/intersection it represents. I thought the St. Lawrence Market and the Flatiron building were especially well done. Would have loved to have seen the Wheat Sheaf Tavern over the years.
I noticed in the credits it was made in 2008. I wonder if this is the first time it's being shared publicly?
CTV is putting them up on demand pretty quickly (next day) or at least Rogers Cable in Toronto is.
And she went to Smith, was a straight, white, blonde, southern Republican! Actually I rather enjoyed the character and was mildly upset when she was replaced.
Pretty sure we had the same drapes, tv and lamp.
No problem. Thanks for your response.

Yes, that's when we learned CJ had been worked for EMILY's List.
In another episode when Amy is talking to Mrs. Bartlet either while working for her or about working for her we earn she worked for EMILY's List.
What I wanted to know was whether Amy and CJ (or another character) ever acknowledged that they had both worked for EMILY's List.

Yes, my encounter was with a person looking for money for a bus ticket. He was well dressed and he had this very long, very detailed, and very sad story.
I guess like telemarketing this method of asking for money works. Or they wouldn't do it.

In my 30+ years living in this city I've never experienced anyone panhandling using an opening line. They usually get right to the point because they know they only have your attention for a nano second. I once had a guy stop me and start with this long, detailed story about his unfortunate experiences that I admit I sort of fell for initially but then I realized his long game and excused myself.
Could the time question be code for are you holding (as in drugs)?

How many episodes are there over the course of seven seasons? Over 150? Doing one podcast per episode per week will take them years to finish the entire show. I somehow doubt they will maintain interest or be able to achieve this due to scheduling, etc. Maybe they should do 2 episodes each week?

I've wondered about what exactly happened to Zoey physically and mentally when she was kidnapped. I do recall her having facial injuries and a broken arm (shoulder?). It was clearly stated at the hospital after her release that she was not sexually assaulted. They did make some reference to PTSD during her Fourth of July celebration appearance at the White House and some carry-through on her healing when she went to stay at the farm with her mother. However, I would have thought the mental part (did the kidnappers verbally abuse her?, what impact did the physical injuries have on her psychologically?) might make someone scarred for life. It's never mentioned in later seasons so we have to assume she recovers completely. Or they just wanted to drop the storyline.
Amy worked for EMILY's list as well. Is this ever mentioned in reference to CJ working there? Not that I can recall.
Pug has rolls on his rolls.
That's a long ass light.
John Goodman was perfect in, "Twenty Five (Season 4, Episode 23)".
I liked how they ended the scene - CJ called for everyone to see the egg, they pulled the camera back then went to credits. We'll never know whose faith was restored.

As I'm in the middle of my second re-watch this reminds how well the show holds up. The storylines, the dialogue, heck even the wardrobe (for the most part) all seem contemporary. All signs of a great show, without a doubt.
This is for...um...research purposes right?
When Sandra left the show I saw an interview where she said she would come back for an appearance if Shonda asked her. I think she'll be in the series finale.
It's a facade. In more ways than one.

I'm the exception. I loved season 2. It's probably my favourite. I think that's because I grew up in a city with strong unions, a dock industry as well as other manufacturing plants that suffered like in Baltimore. In addition, the dock workers reminded me of people I grew up with. Blue collar folks trying their best. For me watching it was like putting on an old, comfortable pair of shoes.
I actually disliked season 4 because I had no interest in the Baltimore school system or following a storyline that focused so much on children.
I recognize I'm in the minority but to each their own.

Except...she's always referred to as Mrs. Bartlet before that and after, even when her licence is reinstated.
BTW, I think it is perfectly legal and acceptable to be called Doctor even if your licence has been revoked. It's your right to practice that has been removed not the degree you received.

Same when Babbage called Abby Ms. Bartlet. She corrected him saying, "It's Dr. Bartlet". In part she was doing this as some external manifestation of an internal dialogue about how her identity as a physician had been affected by her role as First Lady.

I once watched a documentary about Native Americans settling part of Canada. It had reenactments with actors dressed in period costume. In one scene they were paddling in a canoe and one of them was wearing a watch!
I'm just into the first part of Season 4 in this re-watch. That sounds vaguely familiar. Thanks for reminding me.
Wow that's an extensive time line! Thanks for posting.

I think the beginning of the series is more like a few weeks into the term. In one of the early episodes point Josh asks Donna whether he has a desk yet (unless that's a flashback I'm recalling). Also Charlie is interviewed early on and I don't think the president would go 7 or 8 months without a body man.
Divorces take different times for different reasons depending on how complex the separation of assets are, whether any issues are contested or even how long it takes to sign the final papers. Some people sit on this last step for months or even longer. Unless the other party is pushing it nothing will happen. Also the lawyers' schedules can be a factor.

Thanks everyone for your responses.
This is my second re-watch and right now I'm just at the beginning of Season 4.
If I recall correctly there's a scene in the very last episode where they flash forward (??) to a discussion with Bartlet, CJ, Charlie, I think Will Bailey and Kate Harper. I can't recall if Josh or Toby are there but I think there's a discussion with Charlie about Zoey. I know they get back together and I think it ends that way but there's definitely some plot holes over the seasons.
Another thread here has already discussed storyline issues with Charlie's education. I still find it fascinating that they never developed the character of Charlie's sister given the importance she played in his motivation for why he was looking for a job in the first place.

I just started a re-watch and went looking for West Wing podcasts on iTunes. Found Josh's, "The West Wing Weekly" and am loving it! The only problem is that they cover only one episode per week and I watch several per day.
She explains that was her married name and she now goes by Fiderer since her divorce.

WRITING.TITLE: Some plot questions...
WRITING.TEXT:
I don't think Zoey Bartlet appears in Season 3. When she returns in Season 4 she's dating that French guy, Jean Paul. When did Zoey break up with Charlie?
Also I don't think Danny Concannon appears in Season 3 either. I know he went on assignment but was his absence acknowledged at the beginning of Season 3? He just reappears in Season 4.
Toby and his wife Andy attempt to conceive a child through IVF. I believe this is first introduced via flashbacks (Season 3?). Were they still married at the time of the flashback? How much time passed after they got divorced before she got pregnant (did they knowingly attempt to conceive while they were separated/divorced)? I don't get the purpose of this storyline other than to set up the investigation with Andy.
Thanks for any feedback.
RDJ looks like a young Tony Curtis.

Yes, it does seem fair. Interesting that it's never been implemented (to the best of my knowledge). Perhaps it is too expensive for clothes manufacturers to apply these multi-level pricing schemes within each product line??

Based on that logic everyone who buys size small of a shirt, sweater or pair of pants that is priced exactly the same for medium and large, which clearly use more material to make should pay less. For example, $5.00 for size small underwear, $6.00 for medium and $7.00 for large.
Why should smaller people subsidize the clothes for larger people?

Thank you for your response. As I understand your explanation this would imply that if you spent most of your time writing over reading or watching tv it would be easier to write. Is that what you meant? Like a muscle that gets used more works better/faster? If so, I'm not sure this explanation is correct. I spend more time writing than I do reading or watching tv yet it always requires so much more effort to write.

WRITING.TITLE: ELI5: Why must we concentrate more to write out an idea than to read a passage of text and in turn to just watch television?

Was watching recorded show on PVR when it happened. After the alarm and on-screen message I lost my sound. Had to rewind and put on the CC to follow the show when I pressed exit to remove the message. I couldn't even read it; something from the OPP?
I'm not sure this is the best way to make these types of announcements. Do they have permission from the CRTC to interrupt the cable signal? AFAIK there was no warning they would be using this type of system, which makes it more of an annoyance than a service.
